instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, sometimes no display
threads.message:
so, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that's acting weird.
If I plug in the charger, the board will power cycle somewhere between 5-20 times roughly (pulsing the s0 rails)  until it will boot further (I can tell because the optical drive will make a noise). Sometimes I get picture when this happens and it'll work fine for a while, but the screen eventually cuts to black. Other times the screen will stay black but the board will stay on and stop power-cycling
I have replaced <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> so that isn't the problem, sadly
Now, while trying random things I noticed that pressing on <CHIP>U9320</CHIP> while powering on will often result in a successful boot right away, and image on screen also. What's more, the screen will often go black as soon as I stop pressing it. Because of this, I tried reflowing <CHIP>U9320</CHIP> thinking it might solve the problem, but no such luck. The board is behaving exactly the same after the reflow.

So, it's clear to me that there's likely a broken connection somewhere. What would be a good  way of pinpointing where the faulty connection is so I can reflow it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling, sometimes no display
threads.message:
You make pression against dedicated graphics area, not only on analog mux.
You can try the hardware mod to disable GPU; is a tedious job however.

Check first diode mode readings on the GPU side of all connection caps between CPU/GPU.
